meta.name: description
meta.content: ChatGPT helps you get answers, find inspiration and be more productive. It is free to use and easy to try. Just ask and ChatGPT can help with writing, learning, brainstorming and more.

meta.name: keyword
meta.content: ai chat,ai,chap gpt,chat gbt,chat gpt 3,chat gpt login,chat gpt website,chat gpt,chat gtp,chat openai,chat,chatai,chatbot gpt,chatg,chatgpt login,chatgpt,gpt chat,open ai,openai chat,openai chatgpt,openai
A conversational AI system that listens, learns, and challenges

div.div:
I want to create a vs code extension which should have capabilities similar to roocode to configure API Provider You'll find these settings in the Roo Code settings panel (click the icon):
API Provider: Select "OpenAI Compatible". Base URL: Enter the base URL provided by your chosen provider. This is crucial. API Key: Enter your API key. Model: Choose a model. Model Configuration: This lets you customize advanced configuration for the model Max Output Tokens Context Window ---the only feature it needs is to do git compare and generate commit messages similar to the github copilot --generate commit message

div.p: Got it so you basically want a lightweight VS Code extension that:

li.p: Lets the user configure an OpenAI-compatible API provider (like Roo Code does API key, base URL, model, etc.).
Has a single main feature: do a git diff in the current repo and generate a commit message using that API.

div.p: Heres how Id break this down into steps so we can build it:

hr.p: Youll need a basic VS Code extension scaffold:

li.p: Command: "extension.generateCommitMessage"
Settings (in package.json): API Provider, Base URL, API Key, Model, etc.
Logic: Run git diff, send it to the API, get commit message back, insert into Git commit box.

hr.p: In package.json under contributes.configuration, you can define:

div.p: Alright lets break this down.

p.em: "This activation event can be removed as VS Code generates these automatically from your package.json contribution declarations."

hr.p:
Thats because when you declare a command under "contributes.commands", VS Code automatically creates the corresponding activation event (onCommand:<commandId>) for you.
So in your package.json, you dont need:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: If you remove "activationEvents", it will still work VS Code will auto-activate when your command is invoked.
This is because "categories" in package.json only accepts certain predefined category strings for Marketplace display. "SCM" is not valid it should be "SCM Providers".
So instead of:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: You should use:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: Heres a corrected version:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

span.span: "Generate commit messages from git diff using an OpenAI-compatible API"

li.p: Removed "activationEvents".
Changed "SCM" "SCM Providers".
name: The internal extension name (lowercase, no spaces).
displayName: How it appears in VS Code UI.
description: Short explanation.
version: Extension version (semantic versioning).
publisher: Your VS Code publisher name (used when publishing).
engines.vscode: Minimum VS Code version.
categories: Helps users find your extension in Marketplace.
main: Entry JS file for the extension.
contributes.commands: Commands you expose in Command Palette.
contributes.configuration: Settings users can configure in the Settings panel.
dependencies: Node packages the extension needs.

hr.p:
If you want, I can give you a cleaned version of the full extension folder with these fixes so that you can F5-run without any warnings.

div.p: Heres the quick step-by-step to run your VS Code extension locally without publishing it to the Marketplace:

h2.strong: 1 Put the extension files in a folder

li.p: Make a folder (e.g., commit-msg-gen).
Place your package.json, extension.js, .vscodeignore, README.md, and node_modules (after install) there.

hr.p: In the extension folder, run:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: This ensures node-fetch and vscode are installed.

li.p: Open the folder (File Open Folder) in VS Code.
This should be the extension project folder, not your code repo.
Press F5 (or go to Run and Debug Launch Extension).
VS Code will open a new Extension Development Host window this is a sandbox where your extension runs.
In that new window:
Open a Git repo that has staged changes (git add ...).
Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Cmd+Shift+P on Mac), search for Generate Commit Message.
Select it.
The extension will:
Grab git diff --cached.
Send it to your configured API.
Insert the returned commit message into the Git SCM input box.

hr.p: In the Extension Development Host window:

li.p: Open Settings Search Commit Message Generator.
Set:
API Provider: OpenAI Compatible
Base URL: (e.g., https://api.openai.com/v1 or your own endpoint)
API Key: (your key)
Model: (e.g., gpt-4o-mini)
Max Tokens: (200 or so)

hr.p: If you want to use it in your normal VS Code without F5 every time:

li.p: Install vsce (VS Code Extension Manager):

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

li.p: Package your extension:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

li.p: This generates a .vsix file.
Install the .vsix into your VS Code:

p.strong: Command Palette Extensions: Install from VSIX...

li.p: Select your .vsix file.
Restart VS Code extension is now installed like a normal one.

hr.p:
If you want, I can also walk you through packaging this commit-message generator so you have a .vsix ready to install in 1 command.
Do you want me to do that next?

div.p:
When you press F5 and see that list (Node.js, Web App (Chrome), etc.), it means you havent set up a launch configuration for a VS Code extension.
Right now, VS Code thinks you want to debug a regular Node.js project, not an extension.

hr.p: You need a .vscode/launch.json file telling VS Code to launch an Extension Development Host.
Inside your extension project folder, make this file:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

li.p: Save the file.
Press F5.

This time, it should open a new VS Code window called
"Extension Development Host" this is where your extension runs.
In that new window:
Open a git repo with staged changes.
Run your Generate Commit Message command from the Command Palette.

hr.p: If you want, I can also prepare a complete extension folder for you with:

li.p: package.json fixed
.vscode/launch.json ready

All boilerplate working
so you just open and press F5.

div.div:
getting Error: Command failed: git diff --cached error: unknown option cached' usage: git diff --no-index [<options>] <path> <path>
Diff output format options -p, --patch generate patch -s, --no-patch suppress diff output -u generate patch -U, --unified[=<n>] generate diffs with <n> lines context -W, --[no-]function-context generate diffs with <n> lines context --raw generate the diff in raw format --patch-with-raw synonym for '-p --raw' --patch-with-stat synonym for '-p --stat' --numstat machine friendly --stat --shortstat output only the last line of --stat -X, --dirstat[=<param1>,<param2>...] output the distribution of relative amount of changes for each sub-directory --cumulative synonym for --dirstat=cumulative --dirstat-by-file[=<param1>,<param2>...] synonym for --dirstat=files,<param1>,<param2>... --check warn if changes introduce conflict markers or whitespace errors --summary condensed summary such as creations, renames and mode changes --name-only show only names of changed files --name-status show only names and status of changed files --stat[=<width>[,<name-width>[,<count>]]] generate diffstat --stat-width <width> generate diffstat with a given width --stat-name-width <width> generate diffstat with a given name width --stat-graph-width <width> generate diffstat with a given graph width --stat-count <count> generate diffstat with limited lines --[no-]compact-summary generate compact summary in diffstat --binary output a binary diff that can be applied --[no-]full-index show full pre- and post-image object names on the "index" lines --[no-]color[=<when>] show colored diff --ws-error-highlight <kind> highlight whitespace errors in the 'context', 'old' or 'new' lines in the diff -z do not munge pathnames and use NULs as output field terminators in --raw or --numstat --[no-]abbrev[=<n>] use <n> digits to display object names --src-prefix <prefix> show the given source prefix instead of "a/" --dst-prefix <prefix> show the given destination prefix instead of "b/" --line-prefix <prefix> prepend an additional prefix to every line of output --no-prefix do not show any source or destination prefix --default-prefix use default prefixes a/ and b/ --inter-hunk-context <n> show context between diff hunks up to the specified number of lines --output-indicator-new <char> specify the character to indicate a new line instead of '+' --output-indicator-old <char> specify the character to indicate an old line instead of '-' --output-indicator-context <char> specify the character to indicate a context instead of ' '
Diff rename options -B, --break-rewrites[=<n>[/<m>]] break complete rewrite changes into pairs of delete and create -M, --find-renames[=<n>] detect renames -D, --irreversible-delete omit the preimage for deletes -C, --find-copies[=<n>] detect copies --[no-]find-copies-harder use unmodified files as source to find copies --no-renames disable rename detection --[no-]rename-empty use empty blobs as rename source --[no-]follow continue listing the history of a file beyond renames -l <n> prevent rename/copy detection if the number of rename/copy targets exceeds given limit
Diff algorithm options --minimal produce the smallest possible diff -w, --ignore-all-space ignore whitespace when comparing lines -b, --ignore-space-change ignore changes in amount of whitespace --ignore-space-at-eol ignore changes in whitespace at EOL --ignore-cr-at-eol ignore carrier-return at the end of line --ignore-blank-lines ignore changes whose lines are all blank -I, --[no-]ignore-matching-lines <regex> ignore changes whose all lines match <regex> --[no-]indent-heuristic heuristic to shift diff hunk boundaries for easy reading --patience generate diff using the "patience diff" algorithm --histogram generate diff using the "histogram diff" algorithm --diff-algorithm <algorithm> choose a diff algorithm --anchored <text> generate diff using the "anchored diff" algorithm --word-diff[=<mode>] show word diff, using <mode> to delimit changed words --word-diff-regex <regex> use <regex> to decide what a word is --color-words[=<regex>] equivalent to --word-diff=color --word-diff-regex=<regex> --[no-]color-moved[=<mode>] moved lines of code are colored differently --[no-]color-moved-ws <mode> how white spaces are ignored in --color-moved
Other diff options --[no-]relative[=<prefix>] when run from subdir, exclude changes outside and show relative paths -a, --[no-]text treat all files as text -R swap two inputs, reverse the diff --[no-]exit-code exit with 1 if there were differences, 0 otherwise --[no-]quiet disable all output of the program --[no-]ext-diff allow an external diff helper to be executed --[no-]textconv run external text conversion filters when comparing binary files --ignore-submodules[=<when>] ignore changes to submodules in the diff generation --submodule[=<format>] specify how differences in submodules are shown --ita-invisible-in-index hide 'git add -N' entries from the index --ita-visible-in-index treat 'git add -N' entries as real in the index -S <string> look for differences that change the number of occurrences of the specified string -G <regex> look for differences that change the number of occurrences of the specified regex --pickaxe-all show all changes in the changeset with -S or -G --pickaxe-regex treat <string> in -S as extended POSIX regular expression -O <file> control the order in which files appear in the output --rotate-to <path> show the change in the specified path first --skip-to <path> skip the output to the specified path --find-object <object-id> look for differences that change the number of occurrences of the specified object --diff-filter [(A|C|D|M|R|T|U|X|B)...[*]] select files by diff type --output <file> output to a specific file

div.p: That error means your Git version (or environment) doesnt recognize the --cached flag which normally is valid and means show staged changes.
This usually happens if:

li.p: Youre not in a real Git repository.
Youre using a minimal Git version (like in some containers or on Windows Git-for-Windows BusyBox shell) that doesnt support staging.
Youre running git diff from the wrong directory.

h3.strong: 1. Make sure youre in a Git repo

hr.p: In the terminal inside your Extension Development Host window:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: If you see:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: Open a folder that is a Git repo before testing.

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: If its very old (like < 1.5), update it. The --cached flag has been around for years.
If you only need the changes in tracked files (like for commit message generation), you can replace:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: with:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: (--staged is just an alias for --cached but sometimes works in unusual setups)
Or, if you want all changes (staged + unstaged):

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

div.p: Got it the reason youre seeing the Commit message generated! notification but not seeing anything in VS Codes commit message box is that your current extension only displays a notification (via vscode.window.showInformationMessage) it doesnt actually set the commit message in the Source Control input box.
To make the generated commit message appear in VS Codes SCM commit input field, you need to explicitly update the Source Control input box value.
Heres how you can fix it:

hr.p: Open your extension.js (or extension.ts) and replace your commands body with something like:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

span.span: // Example: You would generate your commit message dynamically
// Find the Source Control commit input box

sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p:
That just pops up a toast notification, it doesnt change any editor UI fields.
The vscode.scm.inputBox.value API is what directly interacts with the commit message field in the Source Control view.

li.p: Update your extension.js with the code above.
Reload your extension (Ctrl+Shift+P Developer: Reload Window).
Run your command again the commit message will now be pre-filled in the SCM commit box.

div.p: Got it if your VS Code extension shows the notification "Commit message generated!" but doesnt actually insert the text into the commit message input box, it usually means one of two things:

li.p: The extension is generating the message but not writing it into the Git commit box (maybe due to missing vscode API calls or permission issues).
The extension is writing it to the wrong place (for example, output panel instead of the Git SCM input).

hr.h3: How VS Code handles the Git commit input
hr.p: The commit message box in the Source Control tab is tied to:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: or

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: If your extension only generates the text and shows a notification without assigning it to scmInput.value, it wont appear.
Look for something like:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2

overflow-y-auto p-4

absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2

sticky top-9

bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

If you have multiple SCM providers (e.g., GitHub, Azure Repos), the vscode.scm.inputBox might not be pointing to the active repo.
You might need:

div.p:
Yeah VS Code is basically telling you,
"Hey, you're using the old vscode.scm.inputBox API; please use the new SourceControl.inputBox from the vscode.SourceControl instance you create."
Thats why your commit message isnt appearing the deprecated global scm.inputBox isnt actually tied to your source control in your workspace unless you explicitly create and manage it.
Heres the fixed minimal extension code so it works with the latest VS Code API:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

span.span: // Create a source control instance for this extension
// Set commit message in our SCM input box

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

li.p: Unzip your extension into a folder (say commit-message-generator).
Open VS Code File Open Folder select this folder.
Press F5 to run in a new Extension Development Host window.
Inside the dev host, open the Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P) Run Generate Commit Message.
Check the Source Control tab you should see the generated commit message in the commit message box.

p.br: If you want to actually populate the commit box for Git SCM in the current workspace (instead of a custom SCM), wed have to tap into Gits extension API (vscode.extensions.getExtension('vscode.git')), because VS Code doesnt allow direct manipulation of Gits commit box without using its extension API.

div.p: Great now that your extension is working, heres how you can package it and use it locally in VS Code without publishing it to the Marketplace.

h2.strong: 1. Install vsce (Visual Studio Code Extension Manager)

hr.p: This is the official tool for packaging VS Code extensions.

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: Make sure your folder has at least:

bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

span.span: TS) README.md CHANGELOG.md (optional but recommended) node_modules

hr.p: From your extensions root folder:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary

flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

h2.strong: 4. Install it locally in VS Code

hr.p: Two ways:

li.p: Open VS Code
Press Ctrl+Shift+P (or Cmd+Shift+P on Mac)
Search for "Extensions: Install from VSIX..."
Select your .vsix file

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

li.p: Reload VS Code after installing
Try using your command it should work exactly as when you pressed F5 in dev mode.

p.br:
When testing frequently, you dont have to package every time.
You can press F5 in VS Code to run it in the Extension Development Host window.
Only package when you want to share or install it permanently.

hr.p:
If you want, I can give you a ready-to-run ZIP of your working extension folder so you can just run vsce package right away.
That way, no file structure mistakes will block you.
Do you want me to prepare that ZIP now?

div.p: Yes you can add an action button with an icon inside the commit message input box (like GitHub Copilot does) using the SourceControlInputBox.validateInput or SourceControlInputBox placeholder in combination with SourceControl commands and SCM input decorations.

However, VS Code doesnt have a direct "add-hover-icon-to-input-box" API what GitHub Copilot does is actually add a button to the SCM input box toolbar, not inside the text box itself. Thats why when you hover over it, you get the tooltip "Generate commit message".
Heres how you can replicate it:

hr.p: You can register a command in your extension and link it to the SCM input box.

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

li.p: light-magic.svg and dark-magic.svg should be in your extension's images/ folder.
This icon will appear in the SCM toolbar when your source control is active.

hr.h3: 2. Attach Button to SCM Input Box
hr.p: When creating your SourceControl instance:

hr.p: Youll need two small SVG icons:
These should be ~16px to fit nicely in the SCM input bar.

p.br: You cant inject clickable icons directly inside the input field like an HTML <input> VS Code only supports:

li.p: SCM input box placeholder text
Toolbar buttons with icons
Status bar icons

hr.p: So, the GitHub Copilot "magic wand" is actually a toolbar icon in the SCM view, not an embedded input field icon.

If you want, I can modify your existing extension so it shows a GitHub Copilotstyle magic wand button next to the commit box that generates your commit message when clicked.
That way itll behave almost exactly like Copilots.

div.p:
Here are two minimal SVG icons you can drop into your extensions images/ folder one for light themes (light-magic.svg) and one for dark themes (dark-magic.svg).
Theyre small magic-wand icons styled for visibility on respective backgrounds.
images/light-magic.svg (dark wand for light background)

li.p: Create an images folder at the root of your extension.
Save these two files inside it as light-magic.svg and dark-magic.svg.
Update your iconPath in the code like this:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-2xl relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-bg-elevated-secondary text-token-text-secondary flex items-center gap-4 rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs
overflow-y-auto p-4

li.p: Reload your extension in VS Code (F5) you should see the magic wand button in the SCM toolbar.

div.p: If you want, I can also mimic GitHub Copilots exact hover style so it feels identical.
